China Ministry of Commerce provides China-Laos railway training course for 50 Lao government officials

title: Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) donates 30 computers and 3 laptops to Laotian Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES) for primary schools in Vientiane
description: On August 27, 2019, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) donated 30 computers and 3 laptops to the Laotian Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES). The laptops were to be distributed to 11 secondary schools and primary schools in Vientiane Capital. A handover ceremony for the computers was held in Vientiane Capital on Aug 27 between Deputy Minister of Education and Sports Boualan Silipanya and ICBC Director General Sun Feng Lei.  The financial value of the donation is unknown.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) donates 30 computers and 3 laptops to Laotian Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES) for primary schools in Vientiane

# Description
On August 27, 2019, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) donated 30 computers and 3 laptops to the Laotian Ministry of Education and Sports (MOES). The laptops were to be distributed to 11 secondary schools and primary schools in Vientiane Capital. A handover ceremony for the computers was held in Vientiane Capital on Aug 27 between Deputy Minister of Education and Sports Boualan Silipanya and ICBC Director General Sun Feng Lei.  The financial value of the donation is unknown.
justification: Project focuses on educational support through computer donations, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of computers and laptops to schools, educational sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides a RMB 213 million grant — via an April 2019 ETCA — for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#65712, #65714, #40971, #65786, and #85604)
description: On May 10, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), in which the Chinese Government committed a RMB 100 million grant (captured by linked project ID#65786) for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project.  Then, on December 14, 2017, the Council of Ministers of Lebanon allocated RMB 120 million of additional funding to the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project. This RMB 120 sum came from three grants committed in three ETCAs previously signed by the Lebanese Government and the Chinese Government: a RMB 50 million grant committed in an ETCA signed on February 26, 2013 (captured by linked project ID#65712), a RMB 50 million grant committed in an ETCA signed on December 5, 2013 (captured by linked project ID#65714), and a RMB 20 million grant committed in an ETCA signed on September 10, 2015 (captured by linked project ID#40971) (pg.136 of "CDR Progress Report 2017"). Then, on January 9, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an exchange of letters regarding the project in the presence of Prime Minister of Lebanon Saad Hariri.  Then, on April 11, 2019, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an ETCA, in which the Chinese Government committed a RMB 300 million ($44 million USD) grant to Lebanon for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project and other projects that would be mutually agreed upon by the two governments. The ETCA stipulated that the grant would be disbursed through a bank account (known as "Aid Account No. 1/2018") established between China Development Bank (CDB) and the Banque du Liban (Lebanon’s central bank). This grant was signed after the Council of Ministers of Lebanon approved it via Resolution No. 15 issued on March 21, 2019.  Then, on December 16, 2019, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an agreement allocating RMB 213 million of the RMB 300 million grant proceeds to the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project. The use of the remaining RMB 87 million continued to be unallocated. This project captures the RMB 213 million that was allocated towards the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project. For the unallocated RMB 87 million, see linked project ID#85604.  The purpose of the project was to construct a building for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music (Le Conservatoire libanais national supérieur de musique) in the town of Dbaye (الضبية). The conservatory was designed to cover a land area of 14,386 square meters and have a total floor area of 26,588 square meters. The building was to include a 1,200-seat concert hall, a teaching building (including a 350-seat concert hall), a generator room, other equipment rooms, an underground garage, a reception hall, a security room, and fences. The conservatory, once completed, was expected to will attract musicians from neighboring areas, improve the quality and capacity of musical education in Lebanon, and provide a first-class professional venue for the public to enjoy musical performances. The construction of the conservatory was the first complete project aided by the Chinese Government to the Lebanese Government.  China IPPR International Engineering Co., Ltd. (中国中元国际工程有限公司) was the contractor responsible for project design and management, while China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the general contractor responsible for implementation. Lebanon's Ministry of Culture was also involved in implementation. The Chinese Government provided the design plans for the conservatory to Lebanon's Ministry of Culture on September 19, 2018. The Chinese Government and the Lebanese Government signed the project implementation agreement on October 30, 2018. Then, in April 1, 2019, the project design team from China IPPR International Engineering Co., Ltd. briefed Prime Minister Hariri on the progress and preliminary design of the project.  The project's formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 20, 2019. At the time, the conservatory was expected to be completed within 3 years. However, the implementation of this project was delayed because of the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic. A second formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 18, 2020. On June 16, 2022, it was reported that the conservatory was still under construction.
staff_comments: 1. This project is also known as the Lebanese National Higher Institution of Music Construction Project. The Chinese project title is 援黎巴嫩国家高等音乐学院项目 or 黎巴嫩国家高等音乐学院项目. The French project title is La construction du conservatoire nommé Institut national supérieur de musique. The Arabic project title is المعهد الوطني اللبناني العالي للموسيقى. 2. This project is known as 'Construction of the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music -Additional' in the Lebanese Council for Development and Reconstruction's (CDR) database. The agreement number is 25171 (see 'CDR Funding - Construction of the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music -Additional').3. CDR ('CDR Funding - Construction of the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music -Additional') claims that the USD equivalent of this RMB 300 million grant was $47,008,956 USD, but official sources at the time of signing (such as 'Signature with China') report a $44 million USD figure. Thus, it is possible that the entirety of the RMB 300 million was intended for this project, and the 213 million was just the amount allocated so far. For now, #85604 (which records the rest of the ETCA) should remain in case it is intended for another project.4. As this is an ETCA, which is a financing mechanism specific to China's Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM), AidData has coded MOFCOM as the specific Chinese Government institution responsible for providing this grant.5. A progress report ('CDR Progress Report 2017') from the Lebanese Council for Development and Reconstruction (CDR) says that May 13, 2017 was the signing date of the RMB 10 million ETCA, but other official sources ('Agreement on economic and technical cooperation between China and Lebanon', a press release dated May 10, 2017) identified the signing date as May 10, 2017.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides a RMB 213 million grant — via an April 2019 ETCA — for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#65712, #65714, #40971, #65786, and #85604)

# Description
On May 10, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), in which the Chinese Government committed a RMB 100 million grant (captured by linked project ID#65786) for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project.  Then, on December 14, 2017, the Council of Ministers of Lebanon allocated RMB 120 million of additional funding to the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project. This RMB 120 sum came from three grants committed in three ETCAs previously signed by the Lebanese Government and the Chinese Government: a RMB 50 million grant committed in an ETCA signed on February 26, 2013 (captured by linked project ID#65712), a RMB 50 million grant committed in an ETCA signed on December 5, 2013 (captured by linked project ID#65714), and a RMB 20 million grant committed in an ETCA signed on September 10, 2015 (captured by linked project ID#40971) (pg.136 of "CDR Progress Report 2017"). Then, on January 9, 2018, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an exchange of letters regarding the project in the presence of Prime Minister of Lebanon Saad Hariri.  Then, on April 11, 2019, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an ETCA, in which the Chinese Government committed a RMB 300 million ($44 million USD) grant to Lebanon for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project and other projects that would be mutually agreed upon by the two governments. The ETCA stipulated that the grant would be disbursed through a bank account (known as "Aid Account No. 1/2018") established between China Development Bank (CDB) and the Banque du Liban (Lebanon’s central bank). This grant was signed after the Council of Ministers of Lebanon approved it via Resolution No. 15 issued on March 21, 2019.  Then, on December 16, 2019, the Chinese Government and the Government of Lebanon signed an agreement allocating RMB 213 million of the RMB 300 million grant proceeds to the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project. The use of the remaining RMB 87 million continued to be unallocated. This project captures the RMB 213 million that was allocated towards the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music Construction Project. For the unallocated RMB 87 million, see linked project ID#85604.  The purpose of the project was to construct a building for the Lebanese National Higher Conservatory of Music (Le Conservatoire libanais national supérieur de musique) in the town of Dbaye (الضبية). The conservatory was designed to cover a land area of 14,386 square meters and have a total floor area of 26,588 square meters. The building was to include a 1,200-seat concert hall, a teaching building (including a 350-seat concert hall), a generator room, other equipment rooms, an underground garage, a reception hall, a security room, and fences. The conservatory, once completed, was expected to will attract musicians from neighboring areas, improve the quality and capacity of musical education in Lebanon, and provide a first-class professional venue for the public to enjoy musical performances. The construction of the conservatory was the first complete project aided by the Chinese Government to the Lebanese Government.  China IPPR International Engineering Co., Ltd. (中国中元国际工程有限公司) was the contractor responsible for project design and management, while China State Construction Engineering Corporation (CSCEC) was the general contractor responsible for implementation. Lebanon's Ministry of Culture was also involved in implementation. The Chinese Government provided the design plans for the conservatory to Lebanon's Ministry of Culture on September 19, 2018. The Chinese Government and the Lebanese Government signed the project implementation agreement on October 30, 2018. Then, in April 1, 2019, the project design team from China IPPR International Engineering Co., Ltd. briefed Prime Minister Hariri on the progress and preliminary design of the project.  The project's formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 20, 2019. At the time, the conservatory was expected to be completed within 3 years. However, the implementation of this project was delayed because of the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic. A second formal groundbreaking ceremony was held on December 18, 2020. On June 16, 2022, it was reported that the conservatory was still under construction.
justification: Project is focused on cultural infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of music conservatory building with concert halls, teaching facilities, and supporting infrastructure

title: China donates sewing machines and other equipment to Al-Faisal Education Health and Social Compound in Lebanon in 2019
description: According to a report from the Chinese Embassy in Lebanon, on March 27, 2019, the Chinese Government donated sewing machines and other equipment to the Al-Faisal Education Health and Social Compound in Lebanon. The equipment will help improve the center's training capabilities, the sewing skills of female trainees, the lives of local people, and create employment opportunities. The center is located in Lashaya City and provides free medical, foreign language and vocational skills training for local residents. The sewing machines donated by China will be used in the center's sewing skills training for local women, which will help improve the lives of female students or start their own businesses.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
China donates sewing machines and other equipment to Al-Faisal Education Health and Social Compound in Lebanon in 2019

# Description
According to a report from the Chinese Embassy in Lebanon, on March 27, 2019, the Chinese Government donated sewing machines and other equipment to the Al-Faisal Education Health and Social Compound in Lebanon. The equipment will help improve the center's training capabilities, the sewing skills of female trainees, the lives of local people, and create employment opportunities. The center is located in Lashaya City and provides free medical, foreign language and vocational skills training for local residents. The sewing machines donated by China will be used in the center's sewing skills training for local women, which will help improve the lives of female students or start their own businesses.
justification: Project focuses on social development through vocational training and equipment donation without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of sewing machines and equipment for vocational training, focus on improving lives and creating employment opportunities

title: 18th batch of Chinese peacekeeping force is sent to Lebanon (Linked to #41114)
description: On May 10th, 2019, the 18th batch of China's peacekeeping forces was sent to Lebanon as part of the UN Interim Forces In Lebanon (UNIFIL). They completed their transition ceremony with the 17th teacher on May 27th, 2019, and served a term of one year. 200 peacekeepers were in this batch.   The group was sent due to increasing protests throughout Lebanon and was stationed mostly on the border between Lebanon and Israel. The troops' camps were located in Hanniyah Village in southern Lebanon. They were composed of two plane building platoons, two three-dimensional building platoons and one combat service support platoon equipped with more than thirty types of technical personnel to assist with engineering, construction, medical treatment, consulting, and advice. Their deployment, and the deployment of other peacekeeping forces, was suspended on June 30, 2020 by the UN Secretary-General due to COVID-19.  On August 5, 2020, nine peacekeepers of the eighteenth batch were informed that they would be deployed to Beirut, Lebanon to respond to the explosion on August 4, 2020 as part of an emergency medical team. They will join members of the nineteenth batch also sent to respond. The eighteenth batch's medical units have 30 total members and operate on a rotation period; 15 returned to China on July 28, 2020, and the remaining 15 will be switched out on August 18, 2020.  China has sent UNFIL peacekeeping forces to Lebanon every year from 2006 to 2020. The program was temporarily suspended due to COVID-19 on June 30, 2020, but reinstated in August 2020 to respond to the Beirut explosion. This project is linked to project ID #41114 which details the entirety of the project. For individual project descriptions, see these projects: 1st batch: #67581; 2nd batch: #67578; 3rd batch: #67580; 4th batch #71863; 5th batch #71869; 6th batch: #41110; 7th batch: #67582; 8th batch: #67584; 9th batch: #67587; 10th batch: #67588; 11th batch: #67579; 12 batch: #71901; 13th batch: #67589; 14th batch: #72070; 15th batch: #72071; 16th batch: #66366; 17th batch: #67576; 18th batch: #67574; 19th batch: #72082.
combined_text:

The group was sent due to increasing protests throughout Lebanon and was stationed mostly on the border between Lebanon and Israel. The troops' camps were located in Hanniyah Village in southern Lebanon. They were composed of two plane building platoons, two three-dimensional building platoons and one combat service support platoon equipped with more than thirty types of technical personnel to assist with engineering, construction, medical treatment, consulting, and advice. Their deployment, and the deployment of other peacekeeping forces, was suspended on June 30, 2020 by the UN Secretary-General due to COVID-19.  On August 5, 2020, nine peacekeepers of the eighteenth batch were informed that they would be deployed to Beirut, Lebanon to respond to the explosion on August 4, 2020 as part of an emergency medical team. They will join members of the nineteenth batch also sent to respond. The eighteenth batch's medical units have 30 total members and operate on a rotation period; 15 returned to China on July 28, 2020, and the remaining 15 will be switched out on August 18, 2020.  China has sent UNFIL peacekeeping forces to Lebanon every year from 2006 to 2020. The program was temporarily suspended due to COVID-19 on June 30, 2020, but reinstated in August 2020 to respond to the Beirut explosion. This project is linked to project ID #41114 which details the entirety of the project. For individual project descriptions, see these projects: 1st batch: #67581; 2nd batch: #67578; 3rd batch: #67580; 4th batch #71863; 5th batch #71869; 6th batch: #41110; 7th batch: #67582; 8th batch: #67584; 9th batch: #67587; 10th batch: #67588; 11th batch: #67579; 12 batch: #71901; 13th batch: #67589; 14th batch: #72070; 15th batch: #72071; 16th batch: #66366; 17th batch: #67576; 18th batch: #67574; 19th batch: #72082.

title: China donates 1,067 tons of wheat to Lebanon for Syrian refugees in July 2019
description: According to a report from the Government of China, on July 2, 2019, China delivered 1,067 tons of wheat to Lebanon as humanitarian aid to assist Syrian refugees in Lebanon. An handover certificate on the donation was signed by Lebanese Minister of Social Affairs Richard Kuyumjian and Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon Wang Kejian the same day.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates 1,067 tons of wheat to Lebanon for Syrian refugees in July 2019

# Description
According to a report from the Government of China, on July 2, 2019, China delivered 1,067 tons of wheat to Lebanon as humanitarian aid to assist Syrian refugees in Lebanon. An handover certificate on the donation was signed by Lebanese Minister of Social Affairs Richard Kuyumjian and Chinese Ambassador to Lebanon Wang Kejian the same day.
justification: Humanitarian aid project with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Wheat donation for Syrian refugees, humanitarian focus

title: Middle East Airlines enters into sale and leaseback agreement with BOC Aviation for 5-10 Airbus A321neo aircraft
description: On September 2, 2019, BOC Aviation announced that it had signed a sale and leaseback agreement with Middle East Airlines (MEA) — also known as Air Liban S.A.L. — for a minimum of five, and up to ten new Airbus A321neo aircraft. The value and borrowing terms of the sale and leaseback agreement are unknown. However, it is known that, at the time of the signing of the sale and leaseback agreement, the available list price of an individual A321neo aircraft was $129 million. The aircraft are powered by Pratt & Whitney’s PurePower engines. The aircraft were originally expected to be delivered in 2020 and 2021.  On December 1, 2020, BOC Aviation announced that it had delivered the first two of five new Airbus A321NEO aircraft for lease to Middle East Airlines.
staff_comments: 1. Air Liban S.A.L., more commonly known as Middle East Airlines, is the flag carrier of Lebanon, with its head office in Beirut, near Beirut–Rafic Hariri International Airport. It is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Lebanon’s central bank (Banque du Liban).2. Sale and leaseback (or sale-leaseback) agreements are generally considered to be off-balance-sheet hybrid debt products.3. Given that there is only evidence of two A321neo aircraft being delivered and the unit price of a A321neo aircraft was $129 million at the time that the sale and leaseback agreement was signed, AidData assumes that the value of the sale and leaseback agreement is $258 million for the time being. This issue warrants further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
Middle East Airlines enters into sale and leaseback agreement with BOC Aviation for 5-10 Airbus A321neo aircraft

# Description
On September 2, 2019, BOC Aviation announced that it had signed a sale and leaseback agreement with Middle East Airlines (MEA) — also known as Air Liban S.A.L. — for a minimum of five, and up to ten new Airbus A321neo aircraft. The value and borrowing terms of the sale and leaseback agreement are unknown. However, it is known that, at the time of the signing of the sale and leaseback agreement, the available list price of an individual A321neo aircraft was $129 million. The aircraft are powered by Pratt & Whitney’s PurePower engines. The aircraft were originally expected to be delivered in 2020 and 2021.  On December 1, 2020, BOC Aviation announced that it had delivered the first two of five new Airbus A321NEO aircraft for lease to Middle East Airlines.
justification: The project involves a financial transaction (sale and leaseback agreement) for aircraft, which does not have a direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Sale and leaseback agreement for Airbus A321neo aircraft, financial transaction nature

title: Chinese Government sends 14th Medical Team to Lesotho in 2019
description: On October 14, 2019, the Chinese Embassy in Lesotho hosted a welcome ceremony for the 14th Chinese medical team consisting of 9 members majoring in anesthesiology, gynecology, orthopedics, radiology, internal medicine, acupuncture, and moxibustion. The 14th Chinese Medical team members are from Wuhan Fourth and Fifth Hospital (武汉市第四、第五医院), Wuhan Central Hospital (武汉市中心医院), Dongxihu District People's Hospital (东西湖区人民医院), China Resources Wuhan Iron and Steel General Hospital(华润武钢总医院), and Venezuela's Foreign Exchange and Cooperation Center(委对外交流合作中心). Among them, the medical team undertook the main specialist diagnosis and treatment tasks of the Mortebon Hospital in Laribe, especially the Obstetrics and Gynecology and Orthopedics, and completed more than 11,500 outpatient visits and more than 1,200 major and minor surgeries, including more than 130 emergency surgeries. 4 free clinics and 3 medical tours, more than 900 patients were diagnosed and treated, nearly 10 surgeries were performed, more than 700 people were treated and consulted for employees of Chinese-funded companies in Lesotho and overseas Chinese, and about 210,000 RMB worth of drugs and medical devices was donated to the Lesotho recipient hospitals.   On January 8, 2021, the 14th batch of Chinese (Hubei) medical aid teams to Lesotho completed the 14-month national medical aid mission and entered Shenzhen on December 24, 2020. They arrived in Wuhan by plane on January 8, 2021.  Linked to Project #89245.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government sends 14th Medical Team to Lesotho in 2019

# Description
On October 14, 2019, the Chinese Embassy in Lesotho hosted a welcome ceremony for the 14th Chinese medical team consisting of 9 members majoring in anesthesiology, gynecology, orthopedics, radiology, internal medicine, acupuncture, and moxibustion. The 14th Chinese Medical team members are from Wuhan Fourth and Fifth Hospital (武汉市第四、第五医院), Wuhan Central Hospital (武汉市中心医院), Dongxihu District People's Hospital (东西湖区人民医院), China Resources Wuhan Iron and Steel General Hospital(华润武钢总医院), and Venezuela's Foreign Exchange and Cooperation Center(委对外交流合作中心). Among them, the medical team undertook the main specialist diagnosis and treatment tasks of the Mortebon Hospital in Laribe, especially the Obstetrics and Gynecology and Orthopedics, and completed more than 11,500 outpatient visits and more than 1,200 major and minor surgeries, including more than 130 emergency surgeries. 4 free clinics and 3 medical tours, more than 900 patients were diagnosed and treated, nearly 10 surgeries were performed, more than 700 people were treated and consulted for employees of Chinese-funded companies in Lesotho and overseas Chinese, and about 210,000 RMB worth of drugs and medical devices was donated to the Lesotho recipient hospitals.   On January 8, 2021, the 14th batch of Chinese (Hubei) medical aid teams to Lesotho completed the 14-month national medical aid mission and entered Shenzhen on December 24, 2020. They arrived in Wuhan by plane on January 8, 2021.  Linked to Project #89245.
justification: Project is focused on medical assistance and healthcare services without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical team providing healthcare services, outpatient visits, surgeries, and medical donations
